title: How to Make Your Windows Look Like Stained Glass

steps.headline: Draw or trace the design you want to have for your window.You can cover the entire window or just make a border.
steps.description: * Keep your designs simple to start out with. Small intricate patterns are difficult to do so that they can be seen once the design  is finished. If you want to simulate cut glass designs, draw your base design first, then draw in random connecting lines throughout your base design. *Make sure your design will touch all four sides, or separate any large amount of clear space with a leaded line.

steps.headline: Place clear plastic blank over the design.
steps.description: This can be a purchased sheet or you can use any flat, clear, smooth plastic cover such as those from a disposable container if it is large enough to fit your design.

steps.headline: Trace all the lines of the design with liquid leading.
steps.description: You should practice just making straight lines and circles first to get used to how the liquid flows. You need to be able to control the flow so your lines are even and not blotchy or wiggly.

steps.headline: Allow outline dry for at least 2 hours before adding color for best results.
steps.description: Applying color while leading still wet can result in blurred outlines.

steps.headline: Apply color around the interior of the outline first, making sure that the color touches the leading all the way around, then fill in the area inside.
steps.description: If you don't there will be holes in the design and it will be more difficult to peel off. For large areas, you may use a palette  knife or a small spatula to smooth the color.

steps.headline: Allow design to dry for a minimum of 8 hours.
steps.description: The thicker the application, the longer the drying time. Test several areas before trying to peel off design.

steps.headline: Peel the design off the plastic starting around the outside edges and working inward.
Place design on a clean interior window surface.
steps.description: It will stick on the window and  it can be peeled off and repositioned. If the design doesn't stick, make sure the window is clean and dampen the back of the design slightly with a moist (not wet! )paper towel. If portions of the design fails to stick, press your hand against the area and leave for 5 minutes to warm the area and make it more pliable.

steps.headline: Touch up any holes or tears carefully to avoid running and smearing, and if you wish, apply leading around the window edges.

Place clear plastic blank over the design. This can be a purchased sheet or you can use any flat, clear, smooth plastic cover such as those from a disposable container if it is large enough to fit your design. Trace all the lines of the design with liquid leading. You should practice just making straight lines and circles first to get used to how the liquid flows. You need to be able to control the flow so your lines are even and not blotchy or wiggly. Allow outline dry for at least 2 hours before adding color for best results. Applying color while leading still wet can result in blurred outlines. Apply color around the interior of the outline first, making sure that the color touches the leading all the way around, then fill in the area inside. If you don't there will be holes in the design and it will be more difficult to peel off. For large areas, you may use a palette  knife or a small spatula to smooth the color. Allow design to dry for a minimum of 8 hours. The thicker the application, the longer the drying time. Test several areas before trying to peel off design. Peel the design off the plastic starting around the outside edges and working inward.  Place design on a clean interior window surface. It will stick on the window and  it can be peeled off and repositioned. If the design doesn't stick, make sure the window is clean and dampen the back of the design slightly with a moist (not wet! )paper towel. If portions of the design fails to stick, press your hand against the area and leave for 5 minutes to warm the area and make it more pliable. Touch up any holes or tears carefully to avoid running and smearing, and if you wish, apply leading around the window edges.  Finished.
